29.50.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up,
we are learning about things this week. How

35.82.text:
do you catch a fox in west London. We talk
to a viewer. How do you skin and stuff animals.

43.14.text:
We find an enthusiastic amateur in Sutherland.
First, one of Britain's most popular deer

53.80.text:
Just like Bo and Luke Duke diving into the
General Lee, Roy slides gracefully behind

60.31.text:
the controls of his Argo. With his hip recovering
well from his operation Roy has permission,

66.98.text: sort of, to get stuck into those fallow bucks.

76.87.text:
Just about in tune. We have got..... that
was a slightly younger buck. If we want to

88.33.text:
get an older buck, then we just move the band
down a little bit to the next one and give

91.88.text:
it a bit of this. Now this should be a little
bit deeper.

103.11.text:
Now I have no way mastered this yet and we
are just practising and playing about with

113.24.text:
it and seeing what sort of results we get,
but I had a fantastic go at it the other day

118.62.text:
and called 3 bucks in. One mature buck, one
3 year old and a pricket and there was another

124.77.text:
pricket coming up behind, but he didn't quite
make it to us and they came within 25 yards

129.08.text:
of us. So it was absolutely superb to get
that sort of result. So hopefully we can emulate

134.05.text:
that today and get similar results and get
it on camera, fingers crossed, but this is

138.69.text:
superb. The rut is definitely full on. It
would be aided if it was a little bit cooler,

143.96.text:
I think. By Wednesday it should be really
cutting in, so I think the temperature is

149.08.text:
really dropping down. It was about 14 degrees
this morning, so, I mean it is still ok. We

154.08.text:
just heard a little bit of grunting there,
so we are going to go to 2 or 3 different

158.33.text:
rutting stands, just have a quick look about
and hopefully we will get some results.

163.84.text:
Fallow are spread across central Europe - like
a kind of cervine butter - by the Romans.

169.50.text:
Until recently it was thought that the Normans
introduced them to Great Britain and to Ireland

172.88.text:
for hunting in the royal forests. However
recent finds at a Roman palace in Sussex show

178.10.text:
that fallow deer were introduced into southern
England in the 1st century AD. Maybe these

184.33.text:
are those animal's direct descendants. In
which case, as Erasmus would say, cervus canes

194.43.text:
And here is the dog. This morning he is assisted
by his girlfriend Becky - who's armed with

200.24.text:
antlers and a sense of humour as Roy negotiates
ruts in the terrain and tries not to make

205.86.text:
too much noise with his crutches catching
on the bracken. So, having announced our presence

211.13.text:
to any wildlife in a 3 mile radius, surely
the wind will be in our favour.

217.75.text:
Wind is definitely not good. With the breeze
really there is nothing to speak of, but what

232.79.text:
there is is going right into the rutting stand
and unfortunately this is the only way that

239.17.text:
we can approach it. All I am hoping for is
that we are going to use the dog walkers to

243.65.text:
our advantage this morning, in that the deer
are used to people going through the footpath

251.30.text:
along this way so hopefully they won't be
too distressed when they pick our scent up

252.18.text:
going through, but we will see if we get away
with it on this one.

253.05.text:
So for a change it's not 舛ave Canem' as
dog walkers might be a help instead of a hindrance.

259.21.text:
As we head to the rutting stand Roy is in
two minds about which way to approach it.

264.13.text: However a white doe gives us the answer.

268.63.text:
That doe made the decision for us, although
we are not hearing any grunting. That could

269.99.text:
have been where we had to come quite close
with the argo so they might just be a little

270.10.text:
bit cautious, but that doe obviously made
us behind and she has gone running into the

275.79.text:
rutting stand so she is a little bit hyped
up. I was going to creep up a little bit closer

286.84.text:
and try and call a little bit closer to the
stand because this is quite a distance to

291.70.text:
call a buck out. But with her going in there
it has curtailed their action plan. So we

295.70.text:
are going to set up here, have a call here,
have a little bit of a rattle and see what

307.87.text:
Roy starts blowing and rattling but to no
avail. We move to another favoured spot. We

315.46.text:
stop short and Roy powers through the undergrowth.
We take it steady through the wood and finally

321.65.text:
hear that wonderful fallow roar. Knowing there
will be does about we have to be cautious

329.97.text: otherwise the alarm will be sounded.

333.17.text:
Roy has a blast - it sounds like he's responding
but we're probably too far away for him to

342.42.text:
Finally we get close enough to get under his
skin, and with his manhood being threatened

346.67.text:
this nice looking buck comes out from his
boudoir to have a look-see. He is an old aquaintance

353.47.text: of Roy's who is happy to leave him be.

355.98.text:
Not quite as good a response as I was hoping,
but unfortunately that boy there I have called

364.42.text:
him a couple of times. I have called him when
he was a 3 year old. I actually got him on

365.57.text:
film coming in then and I have called him
another time. So as he was coming up there

370.59.text:
he knew what the game was but he still had
to come in and have a look. He is still looking

372.63.text:
at us. What we did then, we actually started
calling previously just outside of his territory

373.27.text:
and he wasn't that bothered, but this time
we actually got onto the side of the territory,

379.02.text:
onto the side of his leg and started grunting
a little bit, and insulted the poor old boy,

384.82.text:
so he decided to come in and have a look and
investigate. Sometimes you get them coming

388.70.text:
steaming up to you, very similar to roe bucks,
when you are calling roe bucks, but he was

395.89.text:
a little bit more cautious. You don't get
to being that big by being silly.

407.25.text:
It's been a worthwhile outing - and Roy knows
that unless you have a vast area to patrol

412.14.text:
fallow are tough to manage AND produce quality
trophy animals.

416.82.text:
It is something that we need to bear in mind
when we have got a decent rutting stand and

421.07.text:
we have got some bucks coming in, just to
ease off them a little bit and let them come

426.06.text:
and see what can progress. Because so many
people shoot fallow bucks far too early and

430.26.text:
don't let them progress and see how they turn
out. It is only when they really become mature

434.62.text:
animals that you are able to see the quality
and see what you are doing and though he is

439.04.text:
nothing spectacular compared to some of the
park animals and to some of the other fallow

444.58.text:
you will see about, but for wild fallow in
this area, he really is something special.

450.91.text:
Now if you like fallow deer next week we're
in fallow heaven learning all about bow hunting

455.47.text: with Danish professional hunter Max Hunt.

458.02.text:
For several generations fallow deer meet here,
nobody knows why it is exactly this spot.

463.31.text:
The problem is as we are about to hunt with
the bow, we need to get even closer now.

469.08.text:
He takes us to a famous estate in South-West
Hungary to witness some of the most spectacular

477.86.text:
From going after large animals to news about
large animals. It's David on the Fieldsports

496.13.text:
Following our piece last week on poachers
shooting at Andy Crow, Surrey Police has contacted

501.12.text:
members of its anti-rural crime Country Watch
initiative to explain its poor response.

508.25.text:
Surrey says the original call about the incident
was routed to another force, which explains

513.01.text:
the delay. It also says that it was acting
on information that only one shot had been

517.31.text:
fired at Andy and his son rather than lots.
So there you are - one shot? Hardly worth

524.76.text:
WHSmiths' ban on the sale of shooting magazines
to under-14s has drawn fire from magazine

532.78.text:
readers. One of them, James Reynolds has started
a campaign on the petition website Change.org.

537.80.text:
Go to Change.org, put WHSmiths into the search
box where you will find two campaigns. James's

544.99.text:
campaign has more than 6,000 signatures as
we recorded News Stump. The campaign by antis

553.69.text:
There is a new swap shop for shooting, but
without Noel Edmunds. Whether you go grouse,

559.44.text:
or pheasant or pigeon shooting or you are
a stalker, there is a new website for swapping

562.38.text:
shooting and stalking in the UK. Created by
26-year-old keen shooter and stalker Sam Clatworthy,

572.37.text:
Not fairing so well is British airgun company
Theoben, which has gone into administration.

577.50.text:
It does not necessarily mean the end for the
Cambridgeshire-based firm. Three years ago,

582.69.text:
Webley went into administration, but was bought
out and continues to trade today.

588.16.text:
And finally, more and more Americans are going
hunting, shooting and fishing according to

592.46.text:
the US Fish and Wildlife Service. After a
20 year decline, the survey found 11 percent

598.27.text:
more Americans fished in 2011 compared to
2006, and hunting was up 9 percent over the

604.96.text:
same period. In South Dakota, the number of
people hunting increased by 58 percent and

610.92.text: the numbers of people who went fishing doubled.

614.24.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

627.79.text:
Thank you David. Now one of our viewers watched
all the muck and muggage about foxes this

633.36.text:
year on the television and thought to himself,
well I have had the answer for a long time.

637.25.text: We went along to find out more.

639.97.text:
Dealing with foxes in the countryside can
be tricky enough, but imagine what it's like

644.64.text:
when you live in suburbia, where the neighbours
don't take kindly to things that go bang in

651.50.text:
That's the problem facing Keith, a viewer
who lives in Middlesex. He keeps chickens

656.70.text:
and wildfowl in a wildlife oasis surrounded
by suburban towns full of, well, townies.But

664.30.text: he's come up with an ingenious solution...

666.99.text:
Well we were looking around for a quiet method
and one which is acceptable in the area we

674.84.text:
live in. So I set about designing a fox trap
myself. I made mistakes with mark 1, it was

683.16.text:
too small. With my experience now is that
you need to have a fox trap at least 6 foot

689.42.text:
long, so they don't feel frightened of it
when they approach it and it must be strong.

696.12.text:
Foxes are strong animals and light gauge weld
mesh they will bend. The great secret of the

702.55.text:
trap is to have a tunnel with a door either
end. The advantage of that is you can lift

710.13.text:
up both doors, you can bait the tunnel to
get the foxes used to coming into it, seizing

717.57.text:
to be frightened of it and then you set it
and Bob's your uncle.

723.77.text:
It really works. Last year Keith trapped 26
foxes in this one spot, the year before it

730.68.text: was 28. Already this year he's had 15.

734.75.text:
And he's got the film to prove it. This was
filmed by the trail camera he's set up to

741.00.text:
He starts by propping the trap open at both
ends, and placing a bait nearby.

746.24.text:
Then as the fox becomes more confident, he
brings the bait inside.

750.79.text:
Once the fox is walking boldly in for its
meal, he closes one end, sets the trap and...

756.97.text:
Bang, he's caught. This one is looking for
the way out, but he's not going to leave his

763.78.text: So what's the best bait for a suburban fox?

766.48.text:
Quite definitely the favourite bait is, in
spite of the noise that these chickens here,

771.73.text:
it is not chickens, but in fact rabbit, quite
definitely . And in fact we have changed bait

777.27.text:
from a chicken to a rabbit and caught a fox
the next night. No 2 is probably a partridge,

785.80.text:
a pheasant is the next on the list and last,
strangely enough, is a full size cockerel.

792.48.text:
Maybe because a fox looks upon it as slightly
too big and slightly too frightening, I don't

797.91.text: know, but certainly rabbit is number 1.

800.79.text:
That is how to keep your poultry safe from
suburban foxes. All you need is a bit of ingenuity,

806.66.text:
some weldmesh, and a ready supply of rabbits
and partridges.

811.55.text:
From foxes to the map that matters. It is
calendar.

820.81.text:
Now for those seasonal reminders and dates
for the diary.

825.66.text:
With the first quarter last Monday, moon is
waxing jibbus and heading for full on 29th

830.10.text:
October. It's also the end of British summertime
this weekend so school children will be able

835.34.text:
to go out wildfowling, and lamping before
bedtime..but after homework.

841.36.text:
The weekend saw the changeover in Northern
Ireland between the two big deer seasons.

845.31.text:
Red and sika stags and fallow bucks ends on
20th October every year in the Province while

850.65.text:
red and sika hind and fallow does begins on
21st October.

858.17.text:
Next week sees the start of the red and sika
hind and roe and fallow doe in England, Scotland

864.66.text:
As for countryside events, Independent Shooting
Supplies in Mountnessing is holding an open

870.58.text:
evening, starting at 5pm on Thursday the 25th
October. There are bargains galore with Caesar

876.19.text:
Guerini turning up to show off their full
range of guns. Plus there's a charity raffle

880.55.text:
- all proceeds going to the Essex air ambulance
and the star prize is a day's pigeon shooting

885.93.text:
with our own legendary Andy Crow and we'll
be there to film it too.

890.91.text:
The evening goes on until 9 and includes wine
and cheese. For more information call Andrew

904.74.text:
That's it for this week if you want to publicise
an event shoot, vacancy, sale, tea dance,

910.66.text:
weeks or days before the doors swing open
- talk to james ..james@fieldsportschannel.tv

919.93.text:
Now have you ever looked at a badly stuffed
animal and thought well I could do that. Well

924.14.text: here is someone who does do that.

926.77.text:
In the north west Highlands a little cottage
industry is springing up dealing with skins.

932.69.text:
My Dad was actually a poacher in Sutherland.
One of the old kind you know. He always said

938.31.text:
to me try not to waste any of the animal you
kill for the table. So he used to home tan

943.74.text:
the sheep skins, because he took the occasional
sheep or deer hide, rabbit skins anything

947.65.text:
like that and he showed me how to do it. You
can do a squirrel and mink and occasional

957.15.text:
birds. They do look like Frankinstein creations
at the moment, but I am getting there that

962.72.text:
is the thing. It is amazingly tricky when
you think, to skin a fox for example for the

970.44.text:
taxidermy. This one is headless because I
just want the pelt from this. With a fox for

976.47.text:
taxidermy obviously you have to leave the
head on and the legs and feet and when you

981.04.text:
think how fiddly it is to skin the head so
that you are not ripping the eyes and not

986.83.text:
ruining the face so that when you are finished
you have a beautiful fox face at the end of

991.59.text:
it. It is actually quite tricky and time consuming
you know and to skin a fox ready for tanning

999.00.text:
for taxidermy purposes, it will take me about
3

1002.33.text:
hours. I am sure other professional would
do it a lot quicker, but I am getting there.

1006.79.text:
If there are any game keepers or shooters
out there into vermin control who can get

1014.42.text:
fox pelts and send me the fox pelts, because
I just can't get them here. That would be

1019.50.text:
much appreciated. Just take out the body,
leave the legs, the tail end for me, roll

1025.18.text:
it up, freeze it in the freezer, don't tell
the wife, for a couple of nights and then

1030.86.text:
if they could take it out double wrap it in
plastic, tape it up, bung it in a box and

1035.12.text:
post it and don't tell the post office what
they are doing. That would be fantastic.

1042.20.text:
If you would like to find out more or to donate
a fox skin the visit www.northhighlandsheepskins.co.uk

1051.79.text:
From the north west tip of Scotland to the
wider world of hunting on YouTube it is Hunting

1058.34.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1064.78.text:
Thank you to Amanda Clement who sends us this
clip. Watched more than 6 million times since

1069.68.text:
it went up on 8th October, Please Move The
Deer Crossing is an audio clip from a phone-in

1075.12.text:
to an American radio station. A lady called
Donna asks for help getting deer crossing

1080.59.text:
signs moved to lower traffic areas. It might
take you a moment to realise just how stupid

1088.07.text:
Back in the UK and Game Shooting - Pheasant
& Duck is UK01Edmund's instructional video

1092.91.text:
on how much lead to give driven game. He uses
a headcam to show birds going over and the

1098.62.text:
slow-mo is a useful guide on lead. He is clearly
enjoying himself far too much to give a useful

1105.50.text:
Thanks to viewer Terje Kvetsad for suggesting
Kristoffer Clausen's latest from Norway. The

1111.21.text:
Scandinavian survival expert is filming red
stag stalking in thick birch woodland. It

1116.68.text:
is the red rut, so there is the superb sound
of roaring all around as the stalker shoots

1123.68.text:
Now to a fishing film that's had more than
three million views in less than a week. A

1128.83.text:
600lb black marlin jumps into the boat that's
hoked it and lands on the crew. The crew escapes

1134.13.text:
with only minor injuries, the feisty marlin
is released and, as the title points out,

1140.67.text:
On the more sedate banks of the River Mole
in England, JamesMarchington is catching pike

1145.15.text:
with his brother. Less scary and the anglers
escape without injury.

1149.37.text:
Now we're off to America for the last three.
LeatherwoodOutdoors, who sounds more and more

1153.60.text:
like Clint Eastwood, shows how to shoot deer
from a highseat the way our ancestors did.

1158.27.text:
It is the opening day of the early muzzleloader
season in Pennsylvania and rifle he uses is

1163.25.text:
a .50-calibre CVA Flintlock Muzzleloader using
ITX Bullets and Sabots.

1168.19.text:
Thanks to viewer Neil Hawkins for a couple
of good suggestions. Spinning Steel Rabbit

1172.64.text:
Target is a clever reactive steel target made
for small calibre rifles. The target spins

1177.80.text:
when you hit the bulls-eye - or bunny's-heart
in this case. In the words of one art critic

1182.39.text: - it might be art but it's poor welding.

1185.45.text:
Finally a two-day hunt for ground squirrels.
Nikki51888 gets more than 200 of them. The

1191.27.text:
dead land in the film use to be rows of trees,
and the piles of limbs and branches are what

1195.94.text:
are left of them. The green is the neighbouring
maize crop which the animals are now threatening.

1200.95.text:
Rifle is a Ruger 77/17 with a Tasco 6-24x44
scope and Hornady .17HMR ballistic tip ammo.

1208.60.text: That's a lot of squirrels shot.

1210.97.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1214.59.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1223.55.text:
Well if you like shooting you will love the
Shooting Show.

1227.92.text:
It's big on partridge for episode twenty-four,
with features on this game bird north and

1232.60.text:
south of the border. First, it's off to the
Angus glens, where the show follows the Rottal

1237.91.text:
estate's guns and beaters on a day's driven
French partridge shoot. In North Yorkshire,

1243.41.text:
Pete Carr interviews Alan Foster of Farndale,
who's got a new method of producing partridges

1248.74.text:
on a hand-fed pheasant shoot. See his feeder
in action. News includes antis harassing farmers

1256.04.text:
and some joined-up blogging from BASC and
the RSPB. If you are watching this on YouTube,

1261.41.text: click on the link on the screen.

1264.36.text:
We are back next week and if you are watching
this on Youtube, please don't hesitate to

1268.66.text:
hit the subscribe button which is now pretty
well permanently placed up there in the top

1273.24.text:
bar. Or go to our show page www.youtube.com/show/fieldsportsbritain
where you can subscribe to just this show

1281.32.text:
if you want to subscribe to our other material
then it is that button up there or go to our

1286.54.text:
website www.fieldsportschannel.tv where you
can click to like us on Facebook, or follow

1290.54.text:
us on Twitter or scroll down to the bottom,
you can put your email address into our constant

1295.90.text:
contact box and we will constantly contact
you. This has been Fieldsports Britain.
